                                                       FOCUS ON PROGRESS AND CHALLENGES

Extreme Poverty Rate Falls                                                        Percent of Population Living on Less Than $1.25/Day
in Many Countries.
                                                                                         1988-1992
                                                                                         2008-2012                                                                                                              69
 MDG 1: ERADICATE EXTREME POVERTY AND HUNGER
                                                                                                                                                                                             66
                                                                                                               62
In 2010, five years ahead of the target date of 2015, the world reached the
United Nations Millennium Development Goal 1: cutting in half the proportion                                                                          54              54
of people living in extreme poverty. While this global progress is outstanding,         47
progress in particular countries and regions is not as strong. Globally,
1.2 billion people still live on less than $1.25 a day, and disproportionately                                                  37                                                                                     38
large numbers of them live in southern Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. While                                                                                  33
                                                                                                                                                                                                    30
the rate of extreme poverty fell significantly in China and India, their large
populations (more than 2.5 billion combined) mean that they are two of the                     22
                                                                                                                                      20                                    19
top five countries that have the largest share of the global extreme poor.
                                                                                                                    12



SOURCE: World Bank, “Poverty Headcount Ratio at $1.25 a Day (PPP),”
accessed at http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.DDAY.                              World                China            Honduras               India          Indonesia              Senegal            Uganda

                                                                        FOCUS ON PROGRESS AND CHALLENGES

                                                                                                                                                         1970 Male Female                2014 Male Female
Age Structure Has Changed Differently Across
Regions Between 1970 and 2014.                                                                                                                                                        World
In 1970, just under one-half (48 percent) of the world’s population was younger than 20, a nearly equal percentage                                     80+

was ages 20 to 64, and only 5 percent was 65 and older. Today, as a result of lower fertility rates and longer life
                                                                                                                                                      75-79
                                                                                                                                                      70-74

expectancy, the share of global population under age 20 has dropped to about 35 percent, the population between                                       65-69
                                                                                                                                                      60-64

ages 20 and 64 represent 58 percent, and ages 65 and older represent 7 percent. Asia, Latin America, and Oceania                                      55-59
                                                                                                                                                      50-54

all have population age structures similar to the global averages. In 1970, Europe and North America were similar                                     45-49
                                                                                                                                                      40-44

to the world average today, and their slower growth resulted in a current population much older than the global                                       35-39
                                                                                                                                                      30-34

average. Africa’s population is at the other end of the age spectrum—Africa’s current youthful age structure is much                                  25-29
                                                                                                                                                      20-24
like the global average in 1970.                                                                                                                      15-19
                                                                                                                                                      10-14
                                                                                                                                                        5-9
                                                                                                                                                        0-4

  The POPULATION REFERENCE BUREAU informs people around the world about
  population, health, and the environment, and empowers them to use that information to advance the
  well-being of current and future generations.
